title: 112_s3625
content: The effective date for financial disclosure forms of certain officers and employees under the STOCK Act is December 8, 2012, except for forms filed by the President, Vice President, Members of Congress, candidates for Congress, and certain nominated officers. Additionally, a study and report are required within 30 days of enactment. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management must contract with the National Academy of Public Administration to conduct a study on the risks associated with website publication of financial disclosure forms required by the STOCK Act and issue a report with findings and recommendations within 30 days of enactment. The study will examine risks to national security, law enforcement, Federal missions, personal safety, financial security, and privacy of officers, employees, and their families. The National Academy of Public Administration will conduct a study on the risks associated with website publication of financial disclosure forms required by the STOCK Act. The study will examine harm to national security, law enforcement, Federal missions, personal safety, financial security, and privacy of legislative branch officers, employees, and their families. The report must be issued within 6 months of enactment. The National Academy will submit a report to Congress and the President within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The report will include findings of a study on risks related to financial disclosure forms, recommendations to mitigate identified risks, and any other necessary recommendations. Additionally, there will be a reporting requirement for transactions of spouses and children of Federal officers and employees. The Act approved on August 16, 2012, is amended to change the date from September 30, 2012, to January 1, 2013. It also extends to the executive branch and includes technical amendments. The Act approved on August 16, 2012, is amended to change the effective date to January 1, 2013. The amendments made by subsection (a) do not affect requirements for transaction information in reports for the House of Representatives or the executive branch before January 1, 2013. Existing Senate requirements for transaction information for spouses and dependent children remain unchanged. The curr_chunk is about the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
